We're not sitting here bragging about our product because I would tell you it's not good enough yet, but it's got fifty five billion dollars without us doing virtually anything or no marketing and no real stuff like that. So there's a lot of stuff coming, the competition we have to face.

speaker: James Dimon
text: Some of these acquisitions we made will contribute to profit, maybe not exactly in twenty twenty two, and I mentioned the deployment of the balance sheet. We're pretty conservative in the deployment of balance sheet. That may not always be true.

speaker: Jeremy Barnum
text: Follow up and then I'll re queue after my follow up. But as it relates to technology specifically, Jeremy, you talked about retiring technical debt and so that's kind of playing defense. But also on the offensive side, where are you investing for tech where you would expect some more revenues? You talked about digital banking in the UK, are you also going to Brazil? What other countries are you targeting for that?

speaker: Jeremy Barnum
text: Yeah, mean, it's funny. I wouldn't actually describe retiring technical debt as playing defense. I mean, I think that's actually a great example of the whole conversation, which is that retiring technical debt is an easy thing to not do if you're playing defense focused on short term targets. But if you're playing offense for the long term, it's exactly this type of decision that creates some of the frustration that you're articulating that's critical for the long term success of the company. That's mean, Mary

speaker: James Dimon
text: And, tell you this. We spend two billion dollars on brand new data centers, okay, which have all the cloud capability you can have in private data centers and stuff like that. We're still running the old data centers. Now we're not gonna get involved in every time we talk to you, I'll explain every part of the pancake buildup of expenses going in and expenses going out, But all this stuff going to these new data centers, which are now completely up and running, some are, but most of the applications that go in have to be cloud eligible. Most of the data that goes in has to be cloud eligible.

speaker: James Dimon
text: We're running a whole bunch of major programs, which I don't think we disclose, on AWS. And we're working with Google and Microsoft to run some of the stuff in the cloud because we wanna have multiple cloud capabilities. And this year, roughly thirty, forty, fifty percent of all our apps, all our data will be moving to cloud related type of stuff. This stuff is absolutely, totally valuable. I mean, I can't, if you sat in this room and looked at the power of the cloud and big data on risk, fraud, marketing, capabilities, offers, customer satisfaction, dealing with errors and complaints, prospecting, it's extraordinary.

speaker: James Dimon
text: You actually see some of that already in how we manage it. Like for example, with all the fraud and all the cyber and all the ransomware, our fraud costs are down this year. There's a reason for that, it's because we've deployed huge capabilities in those things. So we have to do those things and that's a margin, it'll be hugely valuable for us and you'll see some of that benefit, which is why we're comfortable that we'll continue to grow and expand and earn. Like I said, seventeen percent return on tangible capital, I would take that.

speaker: James Dimon
text: If I could own one hundred percent of the company, it'd be private.

speaker: James Dimon
text: Okay, I'll re queue for my follow up.

speaker: James Dimon
text: Michael asked another very good question about market shares. We expect to go up in retail deposit market share, investment market share, private banking market share, fixed income market share, equity market share, investment banking market share, global market share, payments market share, and security services market share, commercial banking market share, and what did I miss? I'd be surprised if any of them go down. And we're not going to give you the number.

speaker: Jeremy Barnum
text: As per now, we have one last question from Jared Kesse from RBC Capital Markets.

speaker: Jeremy Barnum
text: Thank you. Good morning, Jeremy and Jamie. Jeremy, I'm trying to figure out what the discussion topic is going to be first quarter of twenty twenty three when we talk about fourth quarter numbers. And I think it might have more to

speaker: Jeremy Barnum
text: do with credit than we're hearing

speaker: Jeremy Barnum
text: about on the call today. Can you share with us the underwriting standards that you guys are using compared to what they were at the height of the crisis back in twenty twenty? I'm assuming they're easier today because the economy is stronger. But also can you compare them to twenty nineteen? How has it looked today versus what you guys are doing in twenty nineteen?

speaker: Jeremy Barnum
text: Yeah, sure. So I think broadly for the company, there's no really large change in our credit risk appetite and therefore in our underwriting standards. I think I alluded to a little bit, I alluded a little bit to this earlier, which is there's a subtlety in the card business where if you remember pre pandemic, we had talked about card charge off rates being at three point two five percent and maybe trending a little bit higher over time as a function of some underwriting of some slightly higher risk vintages, still well within our credit box, still within our overall credit risk appetite, but just a slight shift in the composition of the portfolio there. So that happened back then, and we just didn't see it flow through because of obviously the extraordinary dynamics that we experienced with the pandemic. And now we're exiting, you know, the fourth quarter of this year with a card net charge off rate and, you know, I forget the exact number.

speaker: Jeremy Barnum
text: Was something like, you know, one point two percent or something.

speaker: James Dimon
text: Which we which you'll never see again.

speaker: Jeremy Barnum
text: Obviously exceptionally low. So the question then becomes like, so, and then I think somewhere in your question there was also about like, when we sort of leaned into the reopening, how did we modify the credit box and the standards? And the answer to that is that we returned it essentially to the pre pandemic So we were obviously very confident in light of what we were seeing about what

speaker: Jeremy Barnum
text: consumer credit

speaker: Jeremy Barnum
text: conditions were.

speaker: James Dimon
text: It got tightened a little bit and now it's back to what it was

speaker: Jeremy Barnum
text: in the quarter. Exactly, exactly.

speaker: James Dimon
text: None of that was completely material to the results. One of the things in Jeremy's slide, which you pointed out, out, we've been over earning on credit for years, and we expect it eventually to normalize. Could argue how fast and what time, but credit card has been numbers that we've never seen in our lives, middle market's been lower than ever, wholesale's been lower than ever, Mortgage has been lower than ever. Cards, they're all low. Eventually they're going to normalize.

speaker: James Dimon
text: And then we kind of build that into models. And the other thing is the loan book, and this is very important for your own modeling, just assume as the loan book grows, we will add reserves pretty much proportionate to growth in the loan book, all things being equal. Now we've got CECL and all this stuff like that, but so that's a flip to the negative, obviously for next year.
